text:
Salsa is:
• a memoization framework, with
• runtime dependency tracking, so that
• you can update some inputs and (performantly) automatically invalidate the affected caches.
I think that's the best way to think about it.

So any julia functions that have side effects or do things outside the dependency tracking, won't jive with the model. So that might be what you were referring to, <@U6A936746>?

text: This also sounds like it might be useful together with Dagger.jl's checkpointing mechanism. You could have Salsa's `@derived` functions remove Dagger's checkpoint data when inputs change, and tell Dagger to schedule the computation again. Dagger will then recompute only the operations without checkpoint data.

elements.text: This also sounds like it might be useful together with Dagger.jl's checkpointing mechanism. You could have Salsa's
@derived
functions remove Dagger's checkpoint data when inputs change, and tell Dagger to schedule the computation again. Dagger will then recompute only the operations without checkpoint data.

text: Right now, Dagger assumes that checkpoint data is removed by the user for each operation they want recomputed, which is obviously error prone without a package doing it for you.
